![Created with Canva Design. Credit: Author.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/PbkBiz_JfhKH0xTM21KA2.png?height=1440&width=2560)

I was learning about applications of blockchain technology, how smart contracts, third-gen cryptos, and IPFS work, then I came across the **Ethereum Name Service (ENS)**. The idea of ENS seemed pretty obvious to me, but I found that only a few people actually use it. So, I took it upon myself to share it with the world and save them some money and time.

# What is Ethereum Name Service

In the early days of the internet, users had to type a long string of characters just to visit a webpage. This IP address looked something like this `142.250.183.46` Can you recognize which website it is?

That’s google. Copy that address and paste it in a browser to confirm.

**Domain Name Service (DNS)** provided a way to convert the human-readable address to a long, unreadable string of IP address that is readable by the computer. These services keep a track of all the domain names and provide the right IP address when requested.

Where does ENS come in?

The same problem which plagued the early web haunts web 3.0 now. To transfer crypto from one account to another requires a relatively long and cryptic address, which is impossible to remember and easy to mess up.

Unlike visiting websites, where if you mess up the IP address you can retype it again with no consequences; if you mess up the crypto address, you can lose the transferred amount. What’s worse is that now the recipient is angry because he did not receive the payment, and now the sender is broke.

> *The [Ethereum Name Service (ENS)](https://docs.ens.domains/) is a distributed, open, and extensible naming system based on the Ethereum blockchain.*

ENS is a lookup system that converts the long unreadable address to something like `shubhpatni.eth` (you can actually send some eth there 😉). So, you can send ETH or any other cryptocurrency registered by the recipient to this address, and it will automatically send the money to the desired crypto account.

*Note: Make sure to check if the recipient has registered the address for the cryptocurrency you want to send. You can check it by visiting* `https://app.ens.domains/name/{reciepient_name.eth}`

## How ENS works

ENS has a registry smart contract that keeps track of all domain names, sub-domains, owners, resolvers, etc, and allows the owner to change this data. The registry is the backbone of ENS.

The other key component of ENS is the resolver. Resolvers are responsible for translating names into addresses. So, a resolver must handle different types of data such as cryptocurrency addresses, IPFS content hash, user profile, avatar, etc. If need be, we can also add other data types through the EIP standardization process, with no changes in the ENS registry or any other resolvers.

*How do resolver and registry work together?*

Getting data from ENS is a two-step process. First, we need to find the correct resolver from the registry. To do this, we pass the ENS domain name to the register, which returns the address of the resolver. Now, we ask for the desired data from this resolver.

# Benefits of ENS

Enough with the technical details. Now let’s see what you can actually do with an ENS domain and how it is much more than just a DNS for the decentralized web.

## Host IPFS sites

[IPFS (InterPlanetary File System)](http://ipfs.io/) with ENS allows you to host any website in a truly decentralized way. This means your website will be censorship-resistant, immutable, and in a decentralized network. If you don't want your website to end with `.eth` or want to connect your existing domain name to your IPFS hosted site, you can do so.

Here’s a good guide by [Lucas Kohorst](https://medium.com/u/11f6119feee0?source=post_page-----b16762fd16b4-----------------------------------) on how to host your site-

[https://towardsdatascience.com/decentralizing-your-website-f5bca765f9ed](https://towardsdatascience.com/decentralizing-your-website-f5bca765f9ed)

## Store your E-Mail, profile, bio, and other info

ENS allows you to store more than just your cryptocurrency addresses or IPFS site. You can add addresses of other [ENS-supported blockchains](https://github.com/ensdomains/address-encoder), your Twitter profile, bio, avatar, E-mail, and a lot of other things. People can find all these details by just visiting your `.eth` domain.

Here’s a guide by [Brantly Millegan](https://medium.com/u/6b11550a602f?source=post_page-----b16762fd16b4-----------------------------------) on how to set it up-

[https://medium.com/the-ethereum-name-service/guide-for-soulja-boy-to-setting-up-his-eth-name-and-beyond-b382717bdc71](https://medium.com/the-ethereum-name-service/guide-for-soulja-boy-to-setting-up-his-eth-name-and-beyond-b382717bdc71)

So, let’s say you added a BNB address to your domain, you can now receive any BEP20 token. The same is true for any other supported blockchain for which you have registered on ENS.

All ENS domains are registered under the ERC-721 standard, so they are an NFT, which means you can treat these domains as you treat an NFT. You can buy and sell it, transfer it to another account, or use it as collateral on projects which provide that service.

## Don’t worry if you enter the wrong address

title: Provide your public key
body:
## Why provide? Before the email is sent, PipeMail will perform asymmetric encryption on the email based on the principle of cryptography. Asymmetric encryption requires public and private keys, but PipeMail does not provide public and private keys, so where does the key come from? ***The Digital Wallet!*** The wallet contains several sets of public and private keys, so the most basic functions of the wallet are asymmetric encryption and decryption. > From an encryption point of view, a digital wallet is actually an asymmetric encryption key pair library. PipeMail encrypts emails with the public key in the wallet, which allows only those who have the corresponding private key to decrypt the emails. This makes your emails as secure as Bitcoin, and no government agency can snoop on your emails. ***In summary, providing PipeMail with your public key is a prerequisite for using PipeMail.*** > If Bob wants to send an email to Alice, both Bob and Alice need to provide their public key to PipeMail. ## How to provide? **Step one:** Open [PipeMail Dapp](https://pipemail.xyz/home/inbox), and PipeMail will apply to you to obtain your public key: ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/N8ni66x2lHh0X41sY1mbW.png?height=601&width=764) **Step two:** Click the ***Provide*** button ***Attention:*** The public key can be published externally. Disclosing your public key does not put you at risk of losing your funds. The authenticity of this can be verified in the first paragraph of [this wiki link](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public-key_cryptography): [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public-key_cryptography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public-key_cryptography)
If you've read the above, then you can try using [PipeMail](https://pipemail.xyz/) to send your first Web3 email.

title: How to Get an Arduino and Your Smartphone to Talk to Each Other
body:
## A comparison of various Arduino communication methods

![Communicating with your phone](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*C3D_mdK7CNp54IUPCV32JA.png)

Photo by the author. Created with [Canva](https://www.canva.com/).

Imagine being able to communicate with any device from anywhere in the world. You can control your TV, lights, washing machine, dishwasher, toaster, coffee machine — anything you want — just for a few bucks.

You can do it with Arduino. I have a lot of these lying around in my room, ready to automate another device of mine.

In one of my previous [articles](https://codeburst.io/4-simple-steps-to-make-your-home-come-to-life-for-under-10-585bb50d3f3), I covered how you can use Arduino as a switch to turn any device on or off.

Today, I will discuss the pros and cons of various wireless methods used to create communication between Arduino and smartphones. This would not only allow you to use your phone as a switch, but it would also enable it to send specific commands for operations and get the state from Arduino.

## Various Ways to Send and Receive Data

There are multiple ways to set up communication between Arduino and a smartphone, and each one of them is useful in certain cases. Here are a few of them.

## HTTP requests

You can send and receive data using the [HTTP protocol](https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/what-is-web-socket-and-how-it-is-different-from-the-http/#:\~:text=HTTP%20can%20run%20on%20the,protocol%20such%20as%20TCP,%20SCTP.\&text=WebSocket:%20WebSocket%20is%20bidirectional,%20a,ws://%20or%20wss://.). HTTP POST and GET requests are used to establish communication. For this, you can use an [ESP8266-NodeMCU ](https://www.amazon.in/Lolin-NodeMCU-ESP8266-CP2102-Wireless/dp/B010O1G1ES/ref=sr\_1\_1?dchild=1\&keywords=ESP8266+WiFi+Module\&qid=1603484310\&sr=8-1)module. This module can facilitate the connection and even has GPIO ports.

## HTTP (advantages)

*   It is a stateless platform (i.e. the communication between devices is closed when the message is received by the receiver). HTTP is best for scenarios where the data does not need to be fetched frequently.
*   It requires less computational power.

## HTTP (disadvantages)

*   HTTP is comparatively slower than web sockets. A new connection has to be made every time you need to send or receive data.

A good analogy would be chatting: You send a message and wait for the reply to send another message.

## Bluetooth (advantages)

*   You can buy Bluetooth modules for Arduino for very cheap on [Amazon](https://www.amazon.in/RG-Retail-Bluetooth-Module-Arduino/dp/B071LHLLDC) or [eBay](https://www.ebay.com/c/1964725420) and connect them to your smartphone, PC, or smartwatch.
*   Bluetooth consumes less energy than most wireless communication technologies ([2.5 mW](https://docplayer.net/45928637-An-introduction-to-bluetooth-modules-hc-05-hc-06.html)).
*   It is less prone to the interference of data, which can be the case with other wireless methods. It is best for short-range wireless communication.

## Bluetooth (disadvantages)

*   Bluetooth is short-range communication technology and cannot function properly sometimes — even outside a room.
*   It does not allow internet connection. This defeats the purpose of true anytime-anywhere communication.
*   If you have a nerdy group of friends, it is the worst option, as it is prone to interceptions and attacks.

## Online services

You can also use services such as [Blynk](https://blynk.io/), which has a mobile app for smartphones and a library for Arduino to set up communication.

## Online services (advantages)

*   Online services usually won’t require much coding and hard work. Everything is done for you. You just need to connect the dots.
*   Paid services will regularly update and bring more features with time.
*   Allows you to control devices from anywhere in the world, anytime you want.

## Online services (disadvantages)

*   These services are often not free or have restrictions or friction.
*   The service may not have certain features you need.
*   You are at the mercy of a third-party service, which may not be good if you are looking for commercial applications.

## WebSocket (advantages)

*   WebSocket is a stateful protocol (i.e. the connection is open until one of the devices disconnects). Unlike HTTP, web sockets do not need to make a new connection every time they want to send some data.
*   It the best choice for real-time applications such as gaming and trading, where there is a continuous flow of data.

A good analogy would be a phone call: Until a party disconnects, both the parties can talk and communicate.

## WebSocket (disadvantages)

*   It is computationally expensive compared to the HTTP protocol and thus is only used when a real-time connection is necessary.

## Conclusion

To use these technologies, you can either create a mobile app or use[ ESP8266 as a web server](http://randomnerdtutorials.com/) (for HTTP and WebSockets).

Let me know if you need any help.

title: Elaborating on the Lex Fridman  podcast's episode with Saifedean Ammous
body:
[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gp4U5aH_T6A](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gp4U5aH_T6A)

If you don’t know Lex Fridman and particularly his podcast, I’d suggest you to go take a look: it’s rich with interviews to intelligent, stimulating and influential people; I also really like the way Lex conducts the conversation and the fact that every aspect of the topics discussed is often thoroughly explored, given the long form of the product.

This conversation does not make exception, both for the quality of the guest and for the level of analysis.

## Very strong opinions

As Lex declares in the intro, Saifedean expresses some strong opinions both on economics and cryptocurrencies. He uses strong words and stands firmly on his beliefs. 

I won’t comment on economic topics, since I am no expert nor connoisseur; my opinions are here limited to the cryptocurrency space and its application in both the financial and non-financial world.

## Bitcoin as a money technology

Bitcoin is described by Saifedean kind of as an emergent phenomenon of our world. Technology has allowed us to build a permissionless, decentralised, unstoppable ledger of transactions and from this protocol, from this sets of rules, emerges Bitcoin.

Many times during the conversation Bitcoin is described as “the hardest money we’ve ever had”, justifying this statement on his strict monetary policy: a fixed supply and a predictable issuance that decreases over time before finally ending forever.

One comparison is often presented, and not only in this conversation, between Bitcoin and gold: the latter is said to have had the “hard money” status for centuries, given the difficulty of increasing its supply, the durability and wide adoption. 
 Bitcoin improves over this, with a even lower supply growth (it’s already close to that of gold, \~1,5% per year, and halving every 4 years); on top of this Bitcoin is easily transferrable, not confiscable and, most importantly, anyone that has an internet connection has access to it.

From this view, Bitcoin is clearly the winner in the money game, nothing comes close to it and it even beats gold that has managed to be the standard for hundreds if not thousands of years. The future will tell us if it will actually succeed.

## The altcoins

With Bitcoin a whole now asset class has been born. Initially many tried to fork the code and added some tweaks to be able to claim to have created a “better bitcoin” but soon, basically every attempt has failed. The network effect and the complete disappearance of the founder make it unique.

“Every altcoin is a shitcoin” and nothing can even come close to Bitcoin as being money. They’re all security tied to the decisions of a small group of people who has power over the monetary policy and the whole protocol.

This is where I start to disagree with Saifedean view of the cryptocurrency asset class. After the Bitcoin copycats, the concept of distributed ledger has expanded and it arguably first did so with Ethereum. 

Ethereum, and all other smart contracts blockchains, aren’t trying to be money or stores of value, as Bitcoin is. They are not competing with BTC. 
 They’re playing two different games. 

Nobody could beat Bitcoin at its game: it’s the best attempt at digital hard money we have, if it fails, all the other copycats will go down with it, if it succeeds, it’ll trump the competition.

## What different game are smart contracts blockchains playing then?

Ethereum first introduced smart contracts and a long tail of other projects then copied it, tried to improve it, tried to solve the problem from a different angle.

Saifedean talks about Ethereum in the podcast and uses, as usual, very strong words: he doesn’t like it and thinks it’s the mother of all shitcoins and a scam. 

The main critic is about the desire to bring too much data and computation on-chain, making it increasingly more difficult to run a full node and so compromising decentralisation.

And he is right. Running a full node of any smart contract blockchain is more resource-intensive than running a full bitcoin node. Hence Bitcoin is currently more decentralised than any other blockchain. But that’s where it gets interesting.

The end game for smart contracts blockchains (also called layer 1 blockchains) is not to bring all computation and data on a distributed ledger, because that’s not feasible, it wouldn’t be decentralised. 
 The end game is to become the **world settlement and data availability layer**, I know, it’s a mouthful but these things are complicated.

## What’s a settlement and data availability layer?

As of today, every blockchain (exception made for some layer 2s and rollups) requires each node to run every transaction and store a copy of the whole blockchain. Obviously this can’t scale to world-size.

The goal is to leave the main layer just for settling, either of cryptographic proofs of computation (ZK proofs) or fraud proofs (used in optimistic rollups) and data availability. 
 This way the main layer guarantees the correctness of the computation executed elsewhere.

Transactions execution will be handled by external parties (rollups, validiums, volitions, rollups on top of rollups and so on…), which don’t have to distribute computation to a wide number of nodes, so they’re much more scalable. 
 Some of these execution layers will also publish data about transactions on layer 1 which will guarantee its availability for a certain amount of time, such that any part interested in downloading it will be given the chance to do so.

But how will all of this remain decentralised?

## How decentralised scaling is possible: the power of cryptography

Bitcoin exists because of cryptography. Without it, it just wouldn’t work, full stop. But that’s just the first step.

Using a truly decentralised blockchain to settle computation and distribute data is infeasible if you do it the naive way, exactly as it is infeasible to have a globally distributed and trusted ledger of transactions without cryptography.

The latest inventions provide us with solutions to this problem: cryptography allows us to execute computation on one machine, and to generate a proof (a zero-knowledge proof) that such computation has been run correctly. Anyone can then verify that the proof is valid using far less resources than it would take to compute it themselves.

Moreover, cryptography allows us to publish some data and to encode it in such a way that if enough people sample it (they take multiple very small parts of it and verify that is available, this is called **data availability sampling**) everyone is now convinced that such data has been made available and, if they wished, they could’ve downloaded it and analysed it thoroughly themselves.

These technical implementations, along with many more that I may not be aware of or even understand, allow blockchains to scale to a global settlement and data availability layer in a truly decentralised manner.

In the future a whole blockchain correctness will be ensured by a handful of cryptographic proofs, allowing anyone with any machine (even mobile phones) to verify transactions and talk directly to the network without intermediaries.

## But… it takes time

Currently, the only layer 1 blockchain that has a clear intention towards this vision is Ethereum.

Ethereum has been on this path since the proposal of the rollup-centric roadmap. The next upgrades, EIP-4844 and danksharding (I recently wrote a [blogpost](https://mirror.xyz/pdomenico.eth/0Mh53TcyARisM7o9tvaRIV47M30iwj9L41OsUVO4pdE) about the first if you’re interested) will all be about increasing layer 2 scalability.

There also other layer 1s that could be jumping on this path (although with far less network effect and decentralisation) like Cardano, Polkadot, Tezos, Avalanche just to name a few.

The critic of Saifedean to this blockchains is about centralisation both of nodes and of decision making. A truly decentralised protocol, like Bitcoin, does not change, does not implement backwards incompatible upgrades (hard forks) because a developers elite wants to. And that’s true, that’s both a strength and a weakness of Bitcoin in my opinion: nobody can change it, there will only ever be 21 million BTC but also it probably won’t be used for anything else than moving BTC.

### Centralised at first, decentralised at last

As I’ve said, becoming a global, trustless, decentralised settlement layer takes time and effort, it is a hard problem and it can’t be solved in a whitepaper. 
 Protocols need to be born, form a community around them, have active developers to take the right decisions, implement all the technicalities described above and much more, be battle-tested and only then can they become immutable. 

Before all of this happens, these protocols are going to be somewhat centralised. You can’t have a protocol that upgrades without a relatively small number of developers taking the decisions. But again, that’s not the end game: at last, hopefully, the base-layer protocol will remain, the dust will settle and all the innovation will happen on applications and protocols on top of it.

Is this guaranteed to happen? Of course not. It could fail on any of the points I before mentioned. It’s a risk, that’s the tradeoff of being early.

## On proof of stake

The conversation then moves on to debating Proof of Stake. “PoS is the old system, is the FED, is the central banks” this is Saifedean’s opinion.

I dare to dissent. I think that proof of stake, if correctly implemented, can be even better thank proof of work. Here’s why:

#### PoS is not token governance

This is a common misconception. 
 They are not the same thing, at all. I see them as often mistaken for one another. Being proof of stake does not imply that governance decisions will be taken by token holders.

#### PoS rewards stakers fairly, PoW does not

Network participation in PoS is **proportional** to the value of the asset at stake and so proportional to one’s economic means. PoW doesn’t make it proportional.

If you buy 1,000$ worth of ASICs or GPUs for mining, you have to join a mining pool (unless you’re mining a minor cryptocurrency with very low hashrate) and your power over the network is going to be very different (proportionally to money spent obviously) from a mining business who spent millions, has proper infrastructure, efficient machines and a cheap electricity price you would never get at your home.

In PoS, you get the exact same proportional validating power and economic return, no matter if you spend 100$ or 10,000,000$. If you make a small investment, you most likely will have to delegate to a staking pool (exactly like miners do to mining pools) but you’ll compete fairly, no one is going to have a disproportionate advantage because they invested more than you.

#### In PoS money is actually at stake

Let’s say someone tried to attack the network, what would happen?

In PoW, if they managed to get 51% of the hashing power, it’s a disaster. 
 If the network is decentralised enough and there are people actually running full nodes, the attacker can’t steal any money, but can double spend. And that means network security will be heavily compromised and the social layer needs, after the network has suffered substantial damage, especially in reputation, to fork away and exclude the malicious miner(s). 
 But their hashing power is still there, they could plan another attack, they’ve got very little to lose. After attacking one blockchain and making it unusable they could even go on to the next one and the next one after.

In PoS the power a validator has is strictly confined to one and only one network, because it uses a synthetic resource (the blockchain’s native token) instead of hashpower. Plus, the attacker has actual **stake**. That means that if he attacks the network on the best case scenario (for him) he loses almost all his money because the tokens have lost most of their value and in the worst case he’s lost everything because he got slashed and can never attack the network again. He’s back at square 1.

#### PoS is massively more efficient

This doesn’t really need much more explanation. It just is. PoS consumes something like 99.9% less energy than PoW. That’s just a fact.

# In conclusion

I really enjoyed the conversation, I learned a lot and got a chance to test my beliefs and form new opinions. 
 I think is right to firmly stand on one’s beliefs but at the same time keeping an open mind to innovation.

I’m open to discussion about the things I’ve said, hoping to learn even more.

title: What to do when everything is breaking.
body:
## Part 1: Where the human path leads

Macro predictions:

* I think a shorter cycle has bottomed or will shortly. This is the one people expect
  * I expect a further 20% - 40% (from the top) draw down from here if we go down more
* I think a *bigger* cycle may bottom within 3 months to 3 years. This is the one people do not expect
  * This bigger cycle is tied to unsustainable consumption, uneven and unproductive wealth accommulation, a jenga tower of debt, excess fiat money (worldwide), and declining human coordination
    * While not the topic of this musing, I believe this wholly an incentives problem solvable by a new kind of human coordination framework
  * Fewer and worse goods
  * Deteriorating infrastructure
  * Debt bubble popping is *possible* (though I suspect we need to print at least one more big wave before this happens)
  * An unintentionally deep recession (demand destruction — *eye roll*) could shatter the social and political layer (rule of law) before the financial layer
    * If the social layer does not break when these two troughs overlap this year then it will take another 1 - 2 years more degradation
    * One more system shock would shatter it from then on (pandemic, escalting war, etc.)
  * A broken social layer further degrades the supply chain and infrastructure quality
  * The big print / taxation money dump comes.
  * We whipsaw up then down. This hyper-concentrates wealth
  * Another attempt to print problems away. This time populist (i.e. pitchforks)
  * Money printing cannot solve real-world inefficiency.
  * **Snap.**
  * Everything changes. The U.S. is the last to fall, most likely, despite prevailing belief we are weakest. We are relatively very strong, even if weak on a historical self-comparison. This is opportunity **Window #1** (neutral, but high potential either way)
    * Most of the world is under military rule (including the U.S.)
    * *If* optimistic, effective, visionary leaders stand and prevail the U.S. military will give them an increasingly longer leash as we build the new world order (better this time!)
      * Note: it’s possible the military splits into separate factions (it definitely has and will have factions), but they are not likely to war at this stage. External threats should keep our physical violence machine from turning on itself for a time. Since the factions are not warring, I’ll treat them as one for now
    * If positive-sum civilian leaders do not prevail… continue down the sad stack below.
    * Opportunity Window #1 closes.
  * Mostly bad for a while until humans either devolve into historical top-down brutality or rally around our new social and tech tools to build pockets of new experimentation at the social and political layers. This is opportunity **Window #2.** It is potentially long, but painful
    * A relatively clean reboot is not possible now. Most of the world is in tatters as globalization crumbles, borders are redrawn weekly, and ideologies do most of the fighting (but sadly, not all of it)
  * Window #2 closes when one of A or B occurs:
    * A: If those pockets of societal experimentation work well *and* survive, they will grow and that become the new paradigm in time.
      * If these pockets of experimentation die (potentially murdered), we’ll churn at the bottom of history until one such experiment grows
      * We get a real shot at an incredible future, at the cost of hundreds of millions of deaths and billions living in storybook suffering for an unbearable duration
    * B: An unrecoverable destructive event occurs. This requires no further explanation

Given that macro prediction (Window #1 within 3 years, Window #2 as long as we survive), how does one invest their time, money, effort, and attention?

Those are the next essays in this series, *if* you want them. If you found this valuable, consider minting this essay as an NFT and sharing it. Reading shows interest, minting shows conviction.

Do you have conviction? Do you like our odds for Window #1? Fleeting attention is cheap. Righteousness is a feeling, not a solution. Cures are more expensive with each tick of our shared clock.

It’s rare that you can move the needle with just \~$20. At the very least, you’ll get my personal playbook.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/GZGhkHR8hf7SHJqZ6sW1K.png?height=558&width=997)

***Updated : May 2022***

Mission : HASH DAO provides a unified DAO solution for craft cannabis farmers, BIPOC communities, industry professionals, and investors  
 interested in the cannabis space.

Our mission is to cultivate community horticulture for the future of the cannabis space.

HASH DAO has been created to allow easier access in the cannabis space and easier integration into the emerging technologies of the blockchain and Web3. Focusing on farmers who put the plant first and under represented communities. To do this, we start by partnering with Uncle Mac's brand to create the world first Web3 Cannabis brand and community tooling of horticulture. And a growing compilation of automation protocols using smart contracts. HASH DAO Governance seeks to be the future industry standard.

**Creating the Future of Tech, Innovation, & Culture**

Highly Autonomous Systems of Horticulture (**$HASH**) : Utilizing smart contracts to automate and democratize production, supply chain, and governance in the cannabis & psychedelic Industry.

We created $HASH to allow the craft growers who put the plant first and under-represented communities easier access into the cannabis space and the emerging technologies of Web3.

*“Decades of marijuana prohibition and high incarceration rates for marijuana convictions has left many people out of the legal marijuana boom.”*

> **Barriers of Entry + (Profit > People) = Current State of the Cannabis Space**

The multi-billion dollar cannabis industry is entering it’s boom phase as more global cannabis markets arise and support for [U.S. federal legalization](https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/3617) continues to grow support, in 2020 alone the cannabis space grew to over $20 Billion and is projected to 10x in the next decade.

Malpractice and gatekeeping of the cannabis industry has traditionally maximized profits at the cost of the plant or people, and in turn have provided barriers to entry to craft cannabis farmers and the BIPOC community.

Corporate cannabis companies operate and control the majority of the space, leaving legacy operators and small brands without capital solutions to scale their businesses and do not take into consideration all of it’s stakeholders :

* The Growers & Phenotype Hunters
* Cannabis Processing & Technology
* Dispensaries & Deliveries
* Consumers & Community
* Mother Earth

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/oXXVXLuIXOQoXtXRqzBXV.png?height=621&width=904)

The majority of the craft cannabis space, lacks in metrics and does not reward innovation or intellectual property; often operating at the cost of the patient, plant and the planet.

Cancerous pesticides, mold, and in-organic genetically modified flowers have all been out-dated practices utilized in current cannabis horticulture. This is largely due to a profit-driven model of the medicinal plant which has unjustly fined small legacy growers. Incarceration of the BIPOC community for alternative medicine use at a disproportionate rate has since gate-kept entry into the space.

Farming, hash-processing, and cannabis tech are often driven to innovation by financial corporate investors, many times leaving most of the developers, designers, and legacy growers at the short end of the intellectual property stick. Elite genetics are identified by farmers through years of R/D sorting through phenotypes of each strain. Many times big brands  exploit years of hard work and value that passionate master growers put in and often don’t receive proper credit. Certain strains go on to become cultural identities that generate massive value, I.E. the creators and farmers innovate and the investors profit off their intellectual property, currently there is no on-chain authentication process.

Although track-and-trace is currently implemented, most cannabis brands are not completely transparent with their grow methods and techniques of production. There is also massive risk for current cannabis businesses as they have become targets for robberies the past few years. Legal brands are facing counterfeits and knock-offs in the black market. With the integration of digital identities, NFTs/Web3 purchasing, and automation, many of these problems are easily solved.

![Exclusive Libraries of Genetics & Phenos](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-8T4OrLTcNOJxW2vLerl-.jpg?height=1866&width=1536)

*Solution?* Creating community-ownership of the vertically-integrated $HASH Supply Chain of production, processing, distributing, and operating on-chain craft cannabis  compliance geared toward Web3 adoption. Information, data security, and their applications are essential for business optimization and transparency. Although there are many ERP solutions for the industry already, our governance will be centered around cannabis supply chain and DeFi dApps that utilize NFT-based SKU’s to generate active product data and create on-chain interactions that comply with ESG metrics, paving the way for global regulations and the future of the cannabis space.

Community-Governance over the liquidity, yield-farming, and major-user decisions in the tokenization of HASH DAO.

HASH DAO Governance is the future of the industry standard, and to do this we will start by partnering with one successful Emerald Triangle, Northern California craft cannabis-brand with community-staking of its future scaling of operations and expanding a compilation of automation protocols through smart contracts.

**ON-CHAIN SUPPLY NFTs + ACTIVE INVENTORY TRACKING + CRYPTO TRANSACTIONS = Web3 Point of Sale (PoS)**

**World’s First Cannabis DAO Founded On**:

BIPOC-equity and engineered around community-development governed by craft cannabis operators, backed by IRL projects.

**On-Chain Protocols + Smart Contracts = The Automated Horticulture of Tomorrow**

Creating a future:

* Geared to the love and cultivation of the plant and Mother Earth
* Onboarding BIPOC leaders and creatives onto the blockchain
* Compensating intellectual property proportionally to fulfill smart contracts

> **HASH DAO = Power Back in Your Hands**

Reinvention of the Horticulture Supply Chain and Data Distribution via smart contracts that allow for automation and help individuals to create ownership over community-led projects, intellectual property, digital assets, and dApps.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/M6C2p0sNHx37p783TEv9D.jpg?height=822&width=1125)

**First Wins for HASH DAO**

> “Community Ownership of Physical and Digital Assets”

Minting a multi-tiered HASH DAO NFT with the top governance tier going for $10 K, raising a total of $11.5 M for an initial $HASH treasury. As funds become available, proceeds will immediately go to partnering with South Face Mangement to purchase over 30 acres in Mendocino and 40+ acres Humbolt County. This will include the scaling of a vertically-integrated nursery, farm, hash processing, and soon-to-launch retail of award-winning legacy products under Uncle Mac’s brand and South Face Farms Management.

**Project #1 :**  Carry out renovation on the farm and nursery to ensure full-scale ESG-metric compliance and how to bring all aspects of the farm and it’s production on-chain, from SKU NFT’s to utilizing energy consumption data for carbon credit checks. Partnering with Uncle Mac’s, a Northern California craft cannabis brand, & South Face Management, parent company to Flower Wheel Nursery, South Face Farms Cultivation, and Uncle Mac’s brand.

**Project #2 :** Onboard visual and 3D artists who will design branding and assets for the Metaverse and we develop cross-chain NFT’s to be dropped on various play-to-earn games. We will also be acquiring digital plots of real estate to build “Metaverse farms” and “digital dispensaries” where a user can view the product, find out all of it’s information, and have it eventually delivered through an on-chain transaction. Along with digital land we will also be investing in domain names, including various strain names, cannabis celebrities, and psychedelic culture. Explore liquidity pools and yield farming with assets and treasury.

**Project #3 :** For the third project, we’ll be launching Uncle Mac's HASH House is an Emerald Triangle legacy project. This on-chain Hash House is the home lab for Uncle Mac’s production. We will also operate as a wholesale fresh frozen supply chain solution for transportation, storage, distribution and hash toll processing throughout the greater Emerald Triangle area.

**Project #4** : Getting $HASH in your hands. This is our farm-to-table craft cannabis buyers club providing direct-to-consumer access to exclusive SKU’s from legacy brands in the Emerald Triangle. This will include obtaining a retail and event license to launch Nephew’s Automated.

**Project #5 :** Aggregating a library of horticulture public goods & building the Biodiversity BIPOC Glamping Learning Initiative; start building Marijuana for Minorities Program to co-create $HASH University creating content with some of the best small-batch growers and washers in the industry. (Community Online Education)

**Project #6 :** Nephew’s will be applying for its event space license building the foundation for Akasha, an immersive psychedelic A/R Lounge for BIPOC community healing. The distribution and delivery will be a warehouse that will have an on-chain ESG-metric system in the back and a public access immersive art space in the front. We will also be looking into developing a portfolio of boutique cannabis bud and breakfasts in emerging global cannabis markets.

**Project #7 :** We will be finding ERP solutions to develop state-of-the-art horticulture automation and Web3 technologies, based upon on-chain governance and compliance, to pave the way for the international industry standard by working towards meeting ESG-metric compliance. Our final goal is developing complete automation systems without compromising craft horticulture. From driverless deliveries, farm drone surveillance & data collection to utilize machine-learning and AI and to understand buyer behavior, horticulture improvements, growth optimization, etc.

title: DeFi Employs Disintermediation by Design
body:
First published in BanklessDAO’s Decentralized Law, “*Decentralized Finance,”* May 25, 2022.

[https://banklessdao.substack.com/p/decentralized-finance-decentralized?s=r](https://banklessdao.substack.com/p/decentralized-finance-decentralized?s=r)

Financial services regulation is complex and growing more complex each day. Regulators do not always understand which transactions, derivatives, or other financial instruments give rise to the need for regulatory intervention to prevent systemic risk or impact. Complicated financial products precipitated the financial crisis that began in 2007. Those that grew up during or in the wake of the crisis were understandably disillusioned. Legacy financial institutions and other market participants’ avaricious, self-serving, and predatory behavior arguably led to the U.S. federal government’s 700 billion USD bailout of Wall Street intermediaries, while normal people were left with an economy for a period that is now termed the ‘Great Recession’. As a result, developers began to imagine a financial services industry without traditional intermediaries, sparking ‘FinTech,’ and eventually decentralized finance.

![Abstract of legacy financial risk modeling.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-IpVvfMZXeqsuEp8vWyzd.png?height=1330&width=1456)

A core goal of DeFi is to eliminate legacy financial market intermediaries such as investment banks, depository banks, exchanges, clearinghouses, and broker-dealers, and to increase overall liquidity, transparency, velocity of money, and decrease transaction friction. DeFi allows developers to create new types of financial products and services, eliminating aspects of counterparty risk, by allowing financial assets to be exchanged in a trustless way.

### DeFi\[ned\]

![Source: BAP Software](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/LFQYA2E89xUudQkCs17fv.png?height=406&width=650)

DeFi is a commonly used term to describe the ecosystem of financial services built on decentralized blockchain technology, which replace traditional financial intermediaries with freely accessible, autonomous, and transparent on-chain contracts. DeFi protocols adhere to values of permissionless-ness and transparency. DeFi allows people all over the world to lend, borrow, send, or trade assets using non-custodial wallets and without having to involve a bank, broker, or other intermediary. Users can also explore more advanced financial instruments such as leveraged trading, structured products, synthetic assets, insurance underwriting, and market making while always retaining complete control over their assets.

[As of February 2022](https://consensys.net/blog/cryptoeconomic-research/defi-market-commentary-february-2022/), DeFi total market cap continued to reach new all-time highs, and cumulative revenue has grown to over 4.2 billion USD since June 2020. As new DeFi services recreate and reinvent elements of Traditional/Centralized Finance (interchangeably ‘TradFi’ and ‘CeFi’) services, and billions of dollars of digital assets are pledged to DeFi capital pools, policymakers and regulators are faced with challenges in balancing the risks and opportunities presented by this more transparent and permissionless financial system. While DeFi might offer greater efficiencies and opportunities for inclusion, there are also attendant considerations such as the extent of actual decentralization, governance complexities, technical risk, and ultimately systemic risk throughout a burgeoning composable ecosystem.

### Disintermediation Is a Feature, Not a Bug

DeFi was developed as a peer-to-peer method of transacting without reliance on a system of intermediaries that has historically allowed artificial manipulation of markets and opaque redistribution of risk. DeFi represents an affirmative attempt to eliminate intermediaries in financial transactions. Instances where intermediaries have failed to appropriately manage counterparty risk often result in systemic market disruption where the costs of self-interested misconduct are generally externalized to the market and taxpayers.

Notwithstanding the goals of decentralization and the dynamic attributes of distributed digital ledger platforms, many cryptocurrency broker-dealers, clearinghouses, and exchanges currently operating in mainstream markets still rely on elements of traditional financial intermediation. For example, some platforms rely on centralized order books; others centralize aspects of trade execution or settlement. True decentralization is more often than not merely aspirational.

An alternative way to look at DeFi is that it does not actually eliminate financial intermediation, but enables new ways of performing those same intermediary functions through trustless codes and contracts which are programmed to reduce transaction costs and information asymmetry. Based on continuing infrastructure developments, DeFi platforms have the capacity to adapt, reduce, and possibly eliminate institutional intermediation in trading and transactions.

The [Synthetix](https://synthetix.io/) ecosystem is one of the earliest examples of a fully decentralized protocol eliminating traditional counterparty intermediation in derivatives trading. Two more recent innovative composable protocols in the Synthetix ecosystem are [Lyra](https://www.lyra.finance/) and [Kwenta](https://kwenta.io/).

* [Lyra Protocol](https://docs.lyra.finance/faq) is a collection of smart contracts that allow liquidity providers to provide capital for traders to buy or sell options to/from the market via an Automated Market Maker.
* [Kwenta](https://docs.kwenta.io/) is a decentralized derivatives trading platform offering real-world and on-chain synthetic assets. Kwenta is built on the Synthetix protocol and traders can access synthetic liquidity entirely created by SNX token stakers.

There are no direct counterparties for a trade in the Synthetix protocol, but it does use a counterparty-like model where SNX stakers assume a proportion of the Synthetix debt pool when they mint sUSD (synthetic U.S. dollars). While these protocols arguably include aspects of the traditional intermediation process in their code, this automation and decentralization does not require the involvement of a self-interested counterparty or allow transactional opacity.

### Counterparty Risk Management

Despite centralized financial institutions’ demonstrated lack of transparency, consumers and markets seem to place the utmost trust in them. Proponents of the traditional TradFi/CeFi regulatory regime highlight incidents involving technical failures and attacks on DeFi services resulting in loss of capital as reasons for implementing analogous regulation. However, this seems to be a simplistic argument and purposefully ignores repeated systemic failures in TradFi that have resulted from a lack of transparency and appropriate risk management.

Counterparty risk is the possibility that the other party to a transaction, the ‘counterparty’, will default on its obligations to a financial instrument. This could include failure to repay a loan creating a credit risk, or failure to settle a transaction by delivering the specified asset creating a settlement risk. TradFi industry and regulatory ‘initiatives’ to manage counterparty risk generally involve centralized control and regulation. Due to the interconnected contractual and economic nature of the relationships among the largest market participants, one financial institution’s default on its obligations adversely affects the financial institution’s trading partners, hindering their ability to meet their obligations, and so on down the chain. Systemic risk may also occur if an exogenous shock to the financial system causes widespread, contemporaneous losses across financial markets that trigger the collapse of one or more systemically significant financial institutions or a series of financial institutions.

To mitigate the classic ‘run on the bank’ scenario, regulatory efforts have historically focused on prudential measures such as board risk oversight, safeguarding solvency by imposing mandatory capital requirements, limiting the size or types of assets held, and limiting the types of permissible transactions. While regulators have established these mandates, authorities have generally delegated most counterparty risk management oversight to the self-interested market participants themselves. Despite these efforts at regulation and oversight, centralized systems seemingly allow artificial manipulation of risk constraints to benefit the very intermediaries that have been charged with preventing excessive systemic risk. This was recently demonstrated by the Archegos implosion.

### Archegos’s TradFailure

In April 2022, Coindesk contributor [David Z. Morris](https://twitter.com/davidzmorris) somewhat presciently [highlighted](https://www.coindesk.com/layer2/2022/04/29/wall-streets-latest-market-manipulation-scandal-should-be-a-wake-up-call-for-crypto/) the potential systemic impact of counterparty failures in the crypto market — using Archegos as an example and Luna/Terra as an analogous potential risk case. The Archegos example also highlights ongoing issues with opacity and TradFi disclosure and reporting ‘requirements’.

In March 2021, the family office fund Archegos Capital Management [imploded](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2021-04-08/how-bill-hwang-of-archegos-capital-lost-20-billion-in-two-days), causing billions in losses to the prime broker intermediaries (including Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, UBS, Nomura, Deutsche Bank, and Credit Suisse). The quick summary of what occurred is that Archegos duplicatively pledged collateral to multiple brokers to continually leverage-up trades on a portfolio of approximately ten stocks including Viacom, Discovery, and Tencent. The firm utilized total return swaps, which are functionally contracts between the broker and fund providing exposure to an underlying asset. The client gains — or loses — from any changes in asset price, and the broker, not the client, shows up in filings as the registered holder of the shares. As Archegos’ assets increased in value with the bull market, the leveraged position was continually increased. In March 2021, an unexpected drop in Viacom price forced a margin call, and the positions began to unwind as the underlying stock held by the brokers was sold into the market. The market impact of unwinding the heavily leveraged positions eventually led to billions in losses for the involved intermediary banks and impacted the market as a whole — albeit only briefly.

Archegos purposefully utilized various regulatory loopholes — or just ignored reporting requirements — to obfuscate their positions. Even though total return swaps are a legitimate financial instrument, the Archegos incident has focused regulatory attention on the processes and controls used by prime brokers to extend leverage. Archegos betting on certain stocks using total return swaps made it difficult for prime brokers to understand the full extent of Archegos’ positions and leverage. In addition, because Archegos was a family office — as opposed to a traditional fund — it was exempt from registration as an investment adviser with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The SEC and other regulators have suggested they could now start to scrutinize risk management systems more thoroughly, particularly if counterparties use synthetic structures to not only increase leverage but also to avoid disclosing it.

The most concerning aspect of the Archegos implosion is that the intermediaries   involved appear to have been highly culpable in allowing Archegos to take the positions that it did. Wall Street firms invented the swap derivatives used, provided Archegos with [as much as 85 percent margin debt](https://wallstreetonparade.com/2021/04/archegos-wall-street-was-effectively-giving-85-percent-margin-loans-on-concentrated-stock-positions-thwarting-the-feds-reg-t-and-their-own-margin-rules/) on the derivative trades and were collecting a huge amount of fees while also profiting on the stock underlying the leveraged swaps. Archegos is a prime example of where a [failure to properly evaluate counterparty risk](https://www.axios.com/2021/07/30/credit-suisse-archegos-risk), due largely to lack of transparency, caused significant systemic risk. Standard practices for evaluating risk failed because the firms involved were not incentivized to appropriately monitor Archegos, at least until they sustained 10 billion USD in losses.

### More Terra/Luna Stuff, Really?

![Inspiration](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/8fn2kG-1O4bEzbuhU1poC.png?height=1140&width=1028)

Contrast Archegos’ implosion with UST’s depeg on the Terra blockchain and Luna’s consequent debasement. Allegedly, [on-chain data showed](https://www.theblockcrypto.com/post/145944/crypto-researcher-unpacks-why-ust-broke-down-and-what-happens-next) significant selling of UST into other stablecoins for no clear reason — though it seems like it could be because the entire market was precipitously dropping at the time and investors were de-risking. There are already a variety of [semi-conspiracy theories](https://fortune.com/2022/05/13/terra-ust-stablecoin-crash-suspicious-potential-attack-george-soros/) regarding Luna/Terra’s downfall. However, the algorithmic stablecoin structure and UST’s fast growth, seemingly without scaled backing funds, are also just as likely the cause as a concerted attack by an imagined bad actor. While both Archegos’ 10 billion USD implosion and Luna/Terra’s 40 billion USD collapse caused significant pain in the markets, an important distinction is that Luna/Terra’s algorithm, contracts, inflow/outflows, funding, etc. have always been open and on-chain. Arguably, there were no self-interested intermediaries allowing unmitigated counterparty risk to exist in exchange for profit.

The fallout from the Archegos and Luna/Terra incidents will, unfortunately, be what you would expect: more regulation. More centralization will always be the solution offered by regulators. If DeFi cannot protect against counterparty risk through decentralized means, it will be forced to adhere to standards set by centralized regulators. As DeFi evolves, which, and to what extent, regulators attempt to exercise jurisdiction will become increasingly relevant. In the U.S., the DOJ, CFTC, FinCEN, FINRA, and SEC may all attempt to implement some oversight on decentralized platforms and their customers. It is likely that many DeFi tokens will be considered securities and the SEC will mandate increased disclosure requirements. DeFi platforms may also be considered ‘exchanges’ under SEC jurisdiction and be required to submit to ongoing examinations.

The relative lack of centralized governance and intermediaries in DeFi arguably prevents or limits artificial manipulation of markets to redistribute counterparty risk. Given full transparency, decentralized markets may be better suited to assess risk and respond accordingly. DeFi systems should preclude the possibility of being as artificially risk-controlled as TradFi systems, helping limit the potential for poor management and irresponsible trading practices. That said, we also watched Luna/Terra go to zero — dragging Anchor with it — as the result of manipulation or breakdown of the algorithm and despite active intervention to prevent a digital bank run. Notwithstanding, DeFi’s major value lies in its ability to address systematic counterparty risk through disintermediation and transparency.

*The [lawpanda](https://twitter.com/OGLawPanda) is a U.S. attorney with an active litigation and counseling practice. He is a member of BanklessDAO's Legal Guild, LexDAO, the LexPunkArmy, and member/consultant/contributor to a variety of DAOs and protocols. When he’s not writing for Decentralized Law, he is working to reduce friction between on chain and legacy entities through entity structuring and common-sense legal solutions.*

title: HASH DAO ($HASH) Whitepaper
body:
**What is HASH DAO?**

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/GZGhkHR8hf7SHJqZ6sW1K.png?height=558&width=997)

***Updated : May 2022***

Mission : HASH DAO provides a unified DAO solution for craft cannabis farmers, BIPOC communities, industry professionals, and investors  
 interested in the cannabis space.

Our mission is to cultivate community horticulture for the future of the cannabis space.

HASH DAO has been created to allow easier access in the cannabis space and easier integration into the emerging technologies of the blockchain and Web3. Focusing on farmers who put the plant first and under represented communities. To do this, we start by partnering with Uncle Mac's brand to create the world first Web3 Cannabis brand and community tooling of horticulture. And a growing compilation of automation protocols using smart contracts. HASH DAO Governance seeks to be the future industry standard.

**Creating the Future of Tech, Innovation, & Culture**

Highly Autonomous Systems of Horticulture (**$HASH**) : Utilizing smart contracts to automate and democratize production, supply chain, and governance in the cannabis & psychedelic Industry.

We created $HASH to allow the craft growers who put the plant first and under-represented communities easier access into the cannabis space and the emerging technologies of Web3.

*“Decades of marijuana prohibition and high incarceration rates for marijuana convictions has left many people out of the legal marijuana boom.”*

> **Barriers of Entry + (Profit > People) = Current State of the Cannabis Space**

The multi-billion dollar cannabis industry is entering it’s boom phase as more global cannabis markets arise and support for [U.S. federal legalization](https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/3617) continues to grow support, in 2020 alone the cannabis space grew to over $20 Billion and is projected to 10x in the next decade.

Malpractice and gatekeeping of the cannabis industry has traditionally maximized profits at the cost of the plant or people, and in turn have provided barriers to entry to craft cannabis farmers and the BIPOC community.

Corporate cannabis companies operate and control the majority of the space, leaving legacy operators and small brands without capital solutions to scale their businesses and do not take into consideration all of it’s stakeholders :

* The Growers & Phenotype Hunters
* Cannabis Processing & Technology
* Dispensaries & Deliveries
* Consumers & Community
* Mother Earth

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/oXXVXLuIXOQoXtXRqzBXV.png?height=621&width=904)

The majority of the craft cannabis space, lacks in metrics and does not reward innovation or intellectual property; often operating at the cost of the patient, plant and the planet.

Cancerous pesticides, mold, and in-organic genetically modified flowers have all been out-dated practices utilized in current cannabis horticulture. This is largely due to a profit-driven model of the medicinal plant which has unjustly fined small legacy growers. Incarceration of the BIPOC community for alternative medicine use at a disproportionate rate has since gate-kept entry into the space.

Farming, hash-processing, and cannabis tech are often driven to innovation by financial corporate investors, many times leaving most of the developers, designers, and legacy growers at the short end of the intellectual property stick. Elite genetics are identified by farmers through years of R/D sorting through phenotypes of each strain. Many times big brands  exploit years of hard work and value that passionate master growers put in and often don’t receive proper credit. Certain strains go on to become cultural identities that generate massive value, I.E. the creators and farmers innovate and the investors profit off their intellectual property, currently there is no on-chain authentication process.

Although track-and-trace is currently implemented, most cannabis brands are not completely transparent with their grow methods and techniques of production. There is also massive risk for current cannabis businesses as they have become targets for robberies the past few years. Legal brands are facing counterfeits and knock-offs in the black market. With the integration of digital identities, NFTs/Web3 purchasing, and automation, many of these problems are easily solved.

![Exclusive Libraries of Genetics & Phenos](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-8T4OrLTcNOJxW2vLerl-.jpg?height=1866&width=1536)

*Solution?* Creating community-ownership of the vertically-integrated $HASH Supply Chain of production, processing, distributing, and operating on-chain craft cannabis  compliance geared toward Web3 adoption. Information, data security, and their applications are essential for business optimization and transparency. Although there are many ERP solutions for the industry already, our governance will be centered around cannabis supply chain and DeFi dApps that utilize NFT-based SKU’s to generate active product data and create on-chain interactions that comply with ESG metrics, paving the way for global regulations and the future of the cannabis space.

Developing Horticulture Public Goods : BIPOC Horticulture Initiative, Open-Source Library of Genetics, Strains and Phenos, Regenerative Farming Methods & Techniques, Cannabis Production, Processing, Entheogenic Cultivation, Medicinal Protocols, and a Community-Practitioner Directory

Community-Governance over the liquidity, yield-farming, and major-user decisions in the tokenization of HASH DAO.

HASH DAO Governance is the future of the industry standard, and to do this we will start by partnering with one successful Emerald Triangle, Northern California craft cannabis-brand with community-staking of its future scaling of operations and expanding a compilation of automation protocols through smart contracts.

**ON-CHAIN SUPPLY NFTs + ACTIVE INVENTORY TRACKING + CRYPTO TRANSACTIONS = Web3 Point of Sale (PoS)**

**World’s First Cannabis DAO Founded On**:

BIPOC-equity and engineered around community-development governed by craft cannabis operators, backed by IRL projects.

**On-Chain Protocols + Smart Contracts = The Automated Horticulture of Tomorrow**

Creating a future:

* Geared to the love and cultivation of the plant and Mother Earth
* Onboarding BIPOC leaders and creatives onto the blockchain
* Compensating intellectual property proportionally to fulfill smart contracts

> **HASH DAO = Power Back in Your Hands**

Reinvention of the Horticulture Supply Chain and Data Distribution via smart contracts that allow for automation and help individuals to create ownership over community-led projects, intellectual property, digital assets, and dApps.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/M6C2p0sNHx37p783TEv9D.jpg?height=822&width=1125)

> “Community Ownership of Physical and Digital Assets”

Minting a multi-tiered HASH DAO NFT with the top governance tier going for $10 K, raising a total of $11.5 M for an initial $HASH treasury. As funds become available, proceeds will immediately go to partnering with South Face Mangement to purchase over 30 acres in Mendocino and 40+ acres Humbolt County. This will include the scaling of a vertically-integrated nursery, farm, hash processing, and soon-to-launch retail of award-winning legacy products under Uncle Mac’s brand and South Face Farms Management.

**Project #1 :**  Carry out renovation on the farm and nursery to ensure full-scale ESG-metric compliance and how to bring all aspects of the farm and it’s production on-chain, from SKU NFT’s to utilizing energy consumption data for carbon credit checks. Partnering with Uncle Mac’s, a Northern California craft cannabis brand, & South Face Management, parent company to Flower Wheel Nursery, South Face Farms Cultivation, and Uncle Mac’s brand.

**Project #2 :** Onboard visual and 3D artists who will design branding and assets for the Metaverse and we develop cross-chain NFT’s to be dropped on various play-to-earn games. We will also be acquiring digital plots of real estate to build “Metaverse farms” and “digital dispensaries” where a user can view the product, find out all of it’s information, and have it eventually delivered through an on-chain transaction. Along with digital land we will also be investing in domain names, including various strain names, cannabis celebrities, and psychedelic culture. Explore liquidity pools and yield farming with assets and treasury.

**Project #3 :** For the third project, we’ll be launching Uncle Mac's HASH House is an Emerald Triangle legacy project. This on-chain Hash House is the home lab for Uncle Mac’s production. We will also operate as a wholesale fresh frozen supply chain solution for transportation, storage, distribution and hash toll processing throughout the greater Emerald Triangle area.

**Project #4** : Getting $HASH in your hands. This is our farm-to-table craft cannabis buyers club providing direct-to-consumer access to exclusive SKU’s from legacy brands in the Emerald Triangle. This will include obtaining a retail and event license to launch Nephew’s Automated.

**Project #5 :** Aggregating a library of horticulture public goods & building the Biodiversity BIPOC Glamping Learning Initiative; start building Marijuana for Minorities Program to co-create $HASH University creating content with some of the best small-batch growers and washers in the industry. (Community Online Education)

**Project #6 :** Nephew’s will be applying for its event space license building the foundation for Akasha, an immersive psychedelic A/R Lounge for BIPOC community healing. The distribution and delivery will be a warehouse that will have an on-chain ESG-metric system in the back and a public access immersive art space in the front. We will also be looking into developing a portfolio of boutique cannabis bud and breakfasts in emerging global cannabis markets.

**Project #7 :** We will be finding ERP solutions to develop state-of-the-art horticulture automation and Web3 technologies, based upon on-chain governance and compliance, to pave the way for the international industry standard by working towards meeting ESG-metric compliance. Our final goal is developing complete automation systems without compromising craft horticulture. From driverless deliveries, farm drone surveillance & data collection to utilize machine-learning and AI and to understand buyer behavior, horticulture improvements, growth optimization, etc.

title: DeFi Employs Disintermediation by Design

Financial services regulation is complex and growing more complex each day. Regulators do not always understand which transactions, derivatives, or other financial instruments give rise to the need for regulatory intervention to prevent systemic risk or impact. Complicated financial products precipitated the financial crisis that began in 2007. Those that grew up during or in the wake of the crisis were understandably disillusioned. Legacy financial institutions and other market participants’ avaricious, self-serving, and predatory behavior arguably led to the U.S. federal government’s 700 billion USD bailout of Wall Street intermediaries, while normal people were left with an economy for a period that is now termed the ‘Great Recession’. As a result, developers began to imagine a financial services industry without traditional intermediaries, sparking ‘FinTech,’ and eventually decentralized finance.

![Abstract of legacy financial risk modeling.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-IpVvfMZXeqsuEp8vWyzd.png?height=1330&width=1456)

A core goal of DeFi is to eliminate legacy financial market intermediaries such as investment banks, depository banks, exchanges, clearinghouses, and broker-dealers, and to increase overall liquidity, transparency, velocity of money, and decrease transaction friction. DeFi allows developers to create new types of financial products and services, eliminating aspects of counterparty risk, by allowing financial assets to be exchanged in a trustless way.

### DeFi\[ned\]

![Source: BAP Software](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/LFQYA2E89xUudQkCs17fv.png?height=406&width=650)

DeFi is a commonly used term to describe the ecosystem of financial services built on decentralized blockchain technology, which replace traditional financial intermediaries with freely accessible, autonomous, and transparent on-chain contracts. DeFi protocols adhere to values of permissionless-ness and transparency. DeFi allows people all over the world to lend, borrow, send, or trade assets using non-custodial wallets and without having to involve a bank, broker, or other intermediary. Users can also explore more advanced financial instruments such as leveraged trading, structured products, synthetic assets, insurance underwriting, and market making while always retaining complete control over their assets.

[As of February 2022](https://consensys.net/blog/cryptoeconomic-research/defi-market-commentary-february-2022/), DeFi total market cap continued to reach new all-time highs, and cumulative revenue has grown to over 4.2 billion USD since June 2020. As new DeFi services recreate and reinvent elements of Traditional/Centralized Finance (interchangeably ‘TradFi’ and ‘CeFi’) services, and billions of dollars of digital assets are pledged to DeFi capital pools, policymakers and regulators are faced with challenges in balancing the risks and opportunities presented by this more transparent and permissionless financial system. While DeFi might offer greater efficiencies and opportunities for inclusion, there are also attendant considerations such as the extent of actual decentralization, governance complexities, technical risk, and ultimately systemic risk throughout a burgeoning composable ecosystem.

### Disintermediation Is a Feature, Not a Bug

DeFi was developed as a peer-to-peer method of transacting without reliance on a system of intermediaries that has historically allowed artificial manipulation of markets and opaque redistribution of risk. DeFi represents an affirmative attempt to eliminate intermediaries in financial transactions. Instances where intermediaries have failed to appropriately manage counterparty risk often result in systemic market disruption where the costs of self-interested misconduct are generally externalized to the market and taxpayers.

Notwithstanding the goals of decentralization and the dynamic attributes of distributed digital ledger platforms, many cryptocurrency broker-dealers, clearinghouses, and exchanges currently operating in mainstream markets still rely on elements of traditional financial intermediation. For example, some platforms rely on centralized order books; others centralize aspects of trade execution or settlement. True decentralization is more often than not merely aspirational.

An alternative way to look at DeFi is that it does not actually eliminate financial intermediation, but enables new ways of performing those same intermediary functions through trustless codes and contracts which are programmed to reduce transaction costs and information asymmetry. Based on continuing infrastructure developments, DeFi platforms have the capacity to adapt, reduce, and possibly eliminate institutional intermediation in trading and transactions.

The [Synthetix](https://synthetix.io/) ecosystem is one of the earliest examples of a fully decentralized protocol eliminating traditional counterparty intermediation in derivatives trading. Two more recent innovative composable protocols in the Synthetix ecosystem are [Lyra](https://www.lyra.finance/) and [Kwenta](https://kwenta.io/).

* [Lyra Protocol](https://docs.lyra.finance/faq) is a collection of smart contracts that allow liquidity providers to provide capital for traders to buy or sell options to/from the market via an Automated Market Maker.
* [Kwenta](https://docs.kwenta.io/) is a decentralized derivatives trading platform offering real-world and on-chain synthetic assets. Kwenta is built on the Synthetix protocol and traders can access synthetic liquidity entirely created by SNX token stakers.

There are no direct counterparties for a trade in the Synthetix protocol, but it does use a counterparty-like model where SNX stakers assume a proportion of the Synthetix debt pool when they mint sUSD (synthetic U.S. dollars).
